data.title: find widget inserts view zone in the editor scroll event handler
data.body:
This is somewhat unexpected and leads to the view lines being rendered before the view zone is inserted, then the view lines emit a scroll change due to a max line width update, and at that time the find widget decides to insert a view zone.

Steps:
* have tow short files
* try to disable lazy features that would cause editor repaints
* open find&replace
* switch to a different file

The find widget ends up inserting a view zone while the view is rendering. I think it has to do with how the editor is empty, then it has lines, then the max line width is updated, which causes a scrollWidth update in the scroll state, which eventually causes the find widget to insert a view zone in the rendering path of the editor.

![kapture 2017-05-23 at 17 34 42](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/26362526/7c28f04a-3fde-11e7-915f-54679c3c0ef5.gif)

data.title: Layer-breaker in telemetryUtils
data.body: Some functions in `telemetryUtils` use `window.localStorage` which they aren't allows to do because that's only available in a browser context. On a related note, `localStorage` shouldn't be used directly but things should use the `IStorageService`

data.title: Git: Use Preview for Working Tree Diffs
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 and elementary OS 0.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add git repo as working folder
2. Change file in repo
3. Open Git tab, single (not double) click on file under "CHANGES"
4. The diff should open with the tab tile: "filename (Working Tree)", do not modify any contents or double click on tab
5. Open another file
6. Verify tab in step 4 is still open

I will do this for each of the files I have changed and thinking of committing to review my changes before I stage them. I believe the behavior is the same for staged files. This adds many tabs that I really don't need open when I go from one diff to another. I would like the tab to be closed/replaced by a preview. I would think the diff tab would be like any other file tab; therefore if I opened a diff, then opened a file or another diff by single clicking, the diff would be replaced by the new file's preview.

data.title: Environment variable GOOGLE_API_KEY  set by Electron on each launch

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra (10.12.5)

I have an environment variable called `GOOGLE_API_KEY` in one of my projects, and it keeps getting set to this value - `AIzaSyAQfxPJiounkhOjODEO5ZieffeBv6yft2Q`,  for no obvious reasons. 
Only manual `unset` helps, but temporarily.  After relaunching VSCode or opening a new window, the value is set again - it is recognized within the code and shows up in `printenv`within the built-in terminal, but it is not listed in regular Terminal or iTerm, so I guess it is set only for each new window/instance.

What's even more annoying is that this key is expired and it replaces my working key during local development, making it impossible to ignore.
BTW googling it shows that this key is quite "popular" on the web :)

I think that [**this**](https://github.com/electron/electron/blob/master/atom/common/google_api_key.h#L14) may be the culprit, but don't know the codebase that well to fix it on my own. Any help or advice?

data.title: GPG support

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Hello Added GPG support

Closes #5065 

I have added a new Git Config `git.enableCommitSigning` that will tell vscode `smartCommit` to pass the `-S` flag to git. This way all commits menu items, UI commit features will take advantage of this.

You still need to set the git up to signing which can be found here: https://help.github.com/articles/signing-commits-using-gpg/

What will *not* take advantage is if someone uses the terminal to commit (that they will need pass the `-S` themselves)

I have made all changes that I can tell are needed.

If there is anything missing please let me know and I will make changes.

Please note that I didn't find any git tests in the extension.

data.title: Zooming out is settings cursor position off some pixels left in editor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 LTS x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open editor and zoom out (using shortcut or from View menu)
2. On a blank line, type some text (example: 123456789012345...)
3. When typing, the cursor is shown shifting some pixel to the right than the actual position. (It is more noticeable after writing 10-15 characters).

Cursor is shifting proportionally to the actual cursor position; the higher the number of characters the cursor is away from left side, the cursor is shifting more to the right.

In the following image, the cursor is actually at the end of line but showing before the last character:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4369071/26351622/fc3d45f0-3fd5-11e7-8b2f-6c17a827ff15.png)

data.title: Peek Definition menu option missing in the "Peek Definition" window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.1 (f6868fce3eeb16663840eb82123369dec6077a9b, 2017-05-04T21:40:39.245Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-78-generic
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|Bookmarks|alefragnani|0.14.1|
|vscode-tidyhtml|anweber|1.5.0|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.0|
|qore-vscode|qoretechnologies|0.0.1|
|cmake|twxs|0.0.17|
|cmake-tools|vector-of-bool|0.9.4|;


---

It would be very useful sometimes to have the `Peek Definition` menu option available from inside the "Peek Definition" window itself. For example, when you want to "traverse" a chain of definitions but you don't want to open new editor tabs.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In the editor window, right-click on some symbol, then select `Peek Definition` from the menu.
2. In the "Peek Definition" window, right-click on some symbol - now `Peek Definition` is missing from the menu. Only `Go to Definition` is available.

data.title: Add option for config sync across multiple installations
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:1.12.2 (1.12.2)
- OS Version: Mac

This is a suggestion

VCode should have an option to sign in with Outlook.com/hotmail account and all config should be able to sync across multiple installations though user profile. Option to also create multiple configs like Home Config, Weekend Config or Office Config and easier way to switch.

Lot of times we do some coding in office and switch laptop or use a bigger desktop in home. It would be really easy to sync rather than the Github hack sync way of doing the same. 

Cheers!

I would like to add a new search refiner in my result page, I understand that I need to map the property name (refinableString) to a mapped crawled properties in search schema. But I need to deploy this time > 70 sites so I need a way to do this mapping programmatically rather than using the Search Schema UI.
I tried to export the search configuration after adding the mapping in Search Schema and copied the exported xml file to replace my search settings xml and deploy to the infrastructure site, but no luck on that.
Can someone please help me on this? Thanks!

data.title: Add entry file of oniguruma when packing
data.body: The entry file of oniguruma [(src/oniguruma.js)](https://github.com/atom/node-oniguruma/blob/master/package.json#L2) is cleaned when packing, which may cause a `The mode has failed while tokenizing the input` error message when running the distribution.

data.title: Javascript: Single line comment followed by multi-line comment, has incorrect syntax highlighting on multi-line comment
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:13:11.413Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|output-colorizer|IBM|0.1.1|
|material-icon-theme|PKief|2.0.6|
|vscode-theme-onedark|akamud|1.3.2|
|monokai-plusplus|dcasella|1.6.0|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0|
|theme-dracula|dracula-theme|1.17.0|
|php-intellisense|felixfbecker|1.2.2|
|ftp-sync|lukasz-wronski|0.3.3|
|typescript-javascript-grammar|ms-vscode|0.0.20|
|language-stylus|sysoev|1.7.3|
|twig|whatwedo|1.0.2|
|Material-theme|zhuangtongfa|2.8.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new JavaScript document
2. Enter a single line comment using // and some text, then on any new line below without entering any other text, create a multi-line comment using /* and */

The expected result is that the syntax highlighting shows that they're both comments by placing them both in one color, however the actual result is that the second (multi-line) comment is not treated as a comment by the syntax highlighting. Placing text between the two comments fixes the issue
![screen shot 2017-05-23 at 10 05 50](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11057501/26346868/86e387e6-3f9f-11e7-9c90-4ce8727cd7eb.png)

![screen shot 2017-05-23 at 10 06 23](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11057501/26346872/891805fa-3f9f-11e7-99c4-aa2c797ff7ff.png)
